positive.review: A silly, simple tower defense with a fun rock theme. Lighthearted and easy to enjoy.
Fun twist makes it much more enjoyable than a usual TD! Graphics are simple but I don't mind that for a comedy game. Note that there are 240 achievements.

It's seriously a good game.
Music is Great . (I got 3 songs for my personal playlist)
You can eat your food while playing this game.
Get your 240 achievements along with the fun.
Fun mix of tower defense and rock music, simple yet super addictive!
A fun tower defense with music and personality. Place towers, stop enemies, and enjoy the rock soundtrack while playing.

A cool toy with a top view, top defense at an easy level. The game can be completed in 3 hours, or with boom boxes alone. Cool rocking music. It‚Äôs better to take the whole bundle from the cards; the game completely pays for itself.

Bought the game because it was less than a dollar, but that didn‚Äôt reflect its quality. This tower defense game is simple yet unique. I found myself logging back in until I beat every level. For achievement hunters, it‚Äôs also a great game to 100%. Personally, I‚Äôm always looking for games like this to change things up for a bit. Definitely would recommend to friends.

I've been thoroughly impressed with this game! The energetic rock-themed setting and vibrant visuals create an engaging and immersive experience. The gameplay offers a perfect blend of strategy and fast-paced action, keeping me hooked from start to finish. The soundtrack is fantastic, complementing the intense moments and adding to the overall adrenaline rush. The variety of challenges and increasing difficulty levels ensure there's always something new to enjoy. Overall, it's a must-play for fans of both tower defense genres and rock music‚Äîsure to deliver hours of fun and excitement!
Short, punchy, and totally metal!
I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys simple, fun music and tower defense.

I seriously hate games like this, I never enjoy them, they never seem fun to me. But I actually liked this game, it‚Äôs not bad. At least it‚Äôs something you can play to clear your mind, or if you get bored you can have it running in the background. You can also play it if you‚Äôre on the phone with someone and get bored it doesn‚Äôt require much thinking.

A cool toy with a top view, top defense at an easy level. The game can be completed in 3 hours, or with boom boxes alone. Cool rocking music. It‚Äôs better to take the whole bundle from the cards; the game completely pays for itself.

- Pros: Super cheep (only $0.49 on sale), Easy difficulty, Short playtime (about 3-5 hours), Very low system requirements

- Cons: Repetitive levels and background music, Limited variety of defense towers, Light effects are very sparkle so my eyes hurt during play

- Conclusion: If you are a fan of tower defense games or looking for cheap, and low system requirements game, buy it. You may enjoy this game for 30 minutes

negative.review:
At first glance, it looks like a basic but charming tower defence game, something that you could easily justify given the very low entry price. However, there are a few things about this 'game' that really rub me the wrong way

1) The game itself is somewhat shoddily made. UI elements aren't rendered properly, with some being cut off by the top of the screen. The gameplay is so simplistic that it's essentially pointless. You can use the exact same strategy on every single level with no variation or thought required. The difficulty of each level never increases, and it actually gets significantly easier as you go on. Enemy variety is nonexistent; the more health they have, the slower they move, that's all there is to it.

2) It's on sale about as often as it's not. Not a bad thing, but definitely somewhat suspicious, especially when you consider point 3...

3) The game has hundreds of achievements that are handed out for everything you do. 4 achievements for placing and upgrading a tower. 3 achievements for finishing a level. Multiple achievements per level for killing various amounts of each enemy. Each achievement icon is also a letter, number or symbol, making it plainly obvious what the intent is.

[b]Verdict: this is an achievement farmer attached to a barebones game to conceal/justify its existence. It gets thrown on a 50% off sale every few weeks in the hopes of someone buying it because they want to be able to spell out something on their profile with the achievement showcase feature.[/b]
this tower defence game is kinda ahh tbh, especially that you can get btd6 for a dollar more when on sale.
Only eight towers, and the same strategy works for all 40 levels. This game isn't worth it. You shouldn't play it, even if it's free.

Only eight towers, and the same strategy works for all 40 levels. This game isn't worth it. You shouldn't play it, even if it's free.

At first glance, it looks like a basic but charming tower defence game, something that you could easily justify given the very low entry price. However, there are a few things about this 'game' that really rub me the wrong way

1) The game itself is somewhat shoddily made. UI elements aren't rendered properly, with some being cut off by the top of the screen. The gameplay is so simplistic that it's essentially pointless. You can use the exact same strategy on every single level with no variation or thought required. The difficulty of each level never increases, and it actually gets significantly easier as you go on. Enemy variety is nonexistent; the more health they have, the slower they move, that's all there is to it.

2) It's on sale about as often as it's not. Not a bad thing, but definitely somewhat suspicious, especially when you consider point 3...

3) The game has hundreds of achievements that are handed out for everything you do. 4 achievements for placing and upgrading a tower. 3 achievements for finishing a level. Multiple achievements per level for killing various amounts of each enemy. Each achievement icon is also a letter, number or symbol, making it plainly obvious what the intent is.

[b]Verdict: this is an achievement farmer attached to a barebones game to conceal/justify its existence. It gets thrown on a 50% off sale every few weeks in the hopes of someone buying it because they want to be able to spell out something on their profile with the achievement showcase feature.[/b]
